\(\left|\vec{x}\right| == 1\)

pymls.toolbox.plot_cell(L, o=None, ax=None)[source]¶
pymls.toolbox.plot_line3(ax, v, o=None, label=None) → None[source]¶

Add a line to an existing matplotlib.axes instance.

Parameters:

  • ax (matplotlib.axis) – Axis instance to plot on.

  • v (np.ndarray) – Cartesian coodinate.

  • o (np.ndarray, optional) – Cartesian coordinate. The default is (0,0,0).

  • label (str, optional) – Label passed to the line instance. The default is None.

Return type:

None

pymls.toolbox.plot_r3(a, b, c, o=None, ax=None, labels=None)[source]¶
pymls.toolbox.rotation_from_axis_angle(vector: ndarray, angle: float, degree: bool = True) → ndarray[source]¶
\[R(u, \theta) = \cos(\theta) I + \sin(\theta) u_x + (1 - \cos(\theta)) u \otimes u\]

where \(u_x\) is the cross product matrix.

Parameters:

  • vector (np.ndarray) – unit vector.

  • angle (float) – angle.

  • degree (bool, optional) – provided in radians or degrees? The default is degree=True.

Returns:

  • np.ndarray – Rotation matrix (3,3).

  • Reference

  • ——— – Wikipedia: Rotation_matrix#Rotation_matrix_from_axis_and_angle

pymls.toolbox.square(X)[source]¶

X = [(A1,…, AN), … , (B1, …, BN)] -> X(NM, NM) i.e. [(row_1), (row_2), …]
